description:
From Middle English inclinacioun, inclinacyon, from Old French inclination and Latin inclīnātiō.
Morphologically incline +‎ -ation

examples: The inclination of his head increased and he awoke with a start.
The road up to the house had a steep inclination.
His inclination to drink escalated to alcoholism.

entries.meaning: (geometry) The angle of intersection of a reference plane
examples: The astronomer calculated the inclination of the equator or ecliptic of Earth and the orbital planes of each visible heavenly body.
Artillery must take account of a weapon's precise inclination.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A person or thing loved or admired.
examples: you make will be a Discovery of your Inclinations
